user.about: Fine Art photographer living in Los Angeles, CA. I concentrated on videography for several years, but have always maintained a Canon SLR to practice still photography since high school in the late 90s. I taught photography to high school students while in Graduate School. Last year, a photography exhibition featuring my kinetic photography was funded on Kickstarter. Kinetic Light was at Gallery 381 in Los Angeles for several months. Lately, I've been photographing the places I wander to around America. Some of the photos I take are a platform for commenting on the American Dream. I am working on a video synthesizer for the web called Synth that was funded on Kickstarter. I am employed by Mediahound where I am the Lead Web Application Engineer.

photos.name: A Momentary Revelation About Human Nature
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings. I move the camera while exposing the frame.

photos.name: The Burn
photos.description:
This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings. I make handheld movements with a Canon 7D, intentionally painting with available light. The camera itself is the paintbrush, gathering light while I expose the frame for 1-3 secs. In this case, I'm capturing the light of a California sunset.

I'm pretty bored when I go shooting at home. The same landmarks, over and over again. I lay in wait for some extraordinary lighting to capture the beach and California coast. In between HDR landscapes, I find myself playing with light in different ways. With this process, you can walk up to an ordinary flower bed, set up your exposure and focus and begin painting with the flower petals. It's best to find low contrast scenes, with some amazing highlights. I pushed the contrast in this particular photo to make the sunlight coming through the trees pop even more., making it appear like fire. This shot is the original crop.

Camera Raw -> Photoshop CS6 -> HDR Toning Adjustment -> Curves -> Export to JPEG

photos.name: Crashing Light
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of abstract kinetic light paintings where I expose the frame over several seconds using only available light. I used the light from a California sunset for this one. Check out more photos in my profile to see different photos using this same technique.

photos.name: Beam
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings where I abstract my surroundings while exposing the frame. I typically use available light. This particular photo was processed in Camera Raw, HDR Adjustment and post processed in Photoshop CC.

photos.name: Flair
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings. I move the camera while exposing the frame.

photos.name: Falling To Earth
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings where I makes gestural movements during long exposures. Check out some of my other photos for further explanation. This is the original crop, processed in Camera Raw and Photoshop. The orange line is the sun, at sunset peeking through some burning red bushes.

photos.name: Falling Into Gethsemane
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings.

photos.name: Temptation
photos.description:
This work is part of a series of kinetic light paintings where I abstract landscaped areas. This shot was taken handheld w/ DSLR and I move the camera while exposing the frame. The subject matter of an otherwise boring still life becomes a complete abstraction. I used ND8 + Circular Polarizer and processed the photo in Camera Raw and Photoshop. This is not cropped, so what you see is what I captured in camera with some processing to get the highlights and shadows to my liking. 

This was previously called "Passing Through Gethsemane", but I found another good shot that title worked for better. This one is now "Temptation". It is part of a set referencing a passage in the Bible.

photos.name: Deliver Us From Evil
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of light paintings where I abstract flowers or other landscaped areas. This abstraction is captured in camera and then processed in Camera Raw.

photos.name: Passing Through Gethsemane
photos.description:
This shot is part of a series of kinetic light paintings I've been working on for upcoming exhibitions. I move the camera while exposing the frame which produces this abstraction. 

I had titled another photo this but changed its name after processing this shot. This photo a bit different than the linear motions I've been making lately, more freeform and somewhat incidental. 

I shot this with a ND8 filter + Circular Polarizer, walking and moving the camera in a linear motion while exposing for 2 seconds. Even with this much light from the shot, I was able to capture an exposure with shadow and highlight.

photos.name: Brain Matter
photos.description: This photo is part of series of kinetic light paintings where I abstract landscaped areas by moving the camera while exposing the frame. For further explanation, check out some of my other light paintings.I thought the colors in this one were interesting.

photos.name: Believing In Fantasy
photos.description: This shot is part of a series of kinetic light paintings where I abstract landscaped areas. What would otherwise be a boring still life is transformed into a vibrant, abstract composition filled with color and interesting line and form. I move the camera while exposing for 1-4 seconds depending on the amount of light. When I am in broad daylight, I typically shoot with ND and polarizer and I'm finding I need to stack the ND to create shots like this one. This particular shot is not cropped, so the composition you see is what I captured in camera. I processed this photo in Photoshop and Camera Raw.

photos.name: Manic Expressive
photos.description:
If you click on the image to view on a black background, suddenly the lighting pops even more. 

This work is part of a series of kinetic light paintings where I paint with available light, moving the camera while exposing the frame. This photo is part of a mini-series where I abstract states of mental health.  I should check my own sanity as I shake the camera violently in this frame. The zen-like process of producing shots like this one is very theraputic.

photos.name: The Edge of Psychosis
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings where I abstract landscaped areas in Urban and Suburban locations. This one was a bit of an experiment. I really felt a lot of anxiety today so I wanted to create something that expressed how I felt. I really liked how the colors popped after I ran it through HDR toning in Photoshop CC. It doesn't look like a lot in my portfolio, there's some crazy luminance that isn't found in most of my work. This photo reminds me a of a hologram. You might see some more like this one in the coming week.

photos.name: The Soothing Rush Of Ego
photos.description: This photo is part of an ongoing series of Abstract Expressionist Kinetic Light Paintings.

photos.name: Expressing The Inexpressible
photos.description: Kinetic light painting is a calming, meditative act. Deliberate, organic movement with the camera in properly lit environments can make interesting, dream like compositions. What was once an ordinary wilderness scene now becomes the surreal. The composition was completely done in camera, processed in Camera Raw and then post processed with the HDR Adjustment in photoshop to play around with Gamma. Watch out for several more photos with this same technique every night this week. I want to thank Susanne for being my inspiration. If you enjoy this photo, head on over to my set Light Paintings on 500px.

photos.name: Ebb And Flow
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of light paintings where I paint with natural light. Handheld long exposures reveal organic patterns of light and color unseen by the naked eye. Most light painting photographers choose a flashlight, but since I began working in the medium of photography I felt it was more natural to use the camera as the paintbrush. Kinetic light painting usually consists of perfect geometric form, but I prefer the somewhat incidental nature of quick, gestural movements with the camera. 1-6 second exposures either at night or in properly lit daylight yield extraordinary visions of nature. I invite you to take a look at my kinetic light paintings, you may find some interesting work. I will be uploading 1-2 a day on 500px for the next month. Find all my light paintings in my set on 500px. 500px.com/stevebelovarich/sets/light_paintings

photos.name: Bloody Sunday
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings where I abstract landscaped areas.

photos.name: The Illusion Of Vision
photos.description:
This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings. I make handheld movements with a DSLR, intentionally painting with available light. The camera itself is the paintbrush, gathering light while I expose the frame for 1-3 secs. In this case, I'm capturing the light of a California sunset.

I'm pretty bored when I go shooting at home. The same landmarks, over and over again. I lay in wait for some extraordinary lighting to capture the beach and California coast. In between HDR landscapes, I find myself playing with light in different ways. This shot is the original crop.

photos.name: Out Of Time
photos.description:
Slapped some ND and a Polarizer on my lens and started painting with the evening sunlight on the beach after shooting the photos "Summer's End In Hermosa Beach" and "Paddleboarding In Hermosa Beach At Dusk". This one is minimal and a bit different than my other abstract works.

I went back and forth with the crop until I settled on the original shot. I like to keep the composition that I made in camera, so even though its unlevel I don't really mind.

photos.name: Portal
photos.description: "Portal" is an Abstract Fine Art Photograph. This photo is a kinetic light painting. I move the camera while exposing the sensor. Lately I've been using the light from sunsets here in California. I like to fill the frame with color, depth and contrast. Instead of line, I prefer broader strokes than most light painters.

photos.name: Far, Far Away
photos.description:
Caught this shot while walking in a wilderness park in Redondo Beach. Thought the colors were very representative of those found in Southern California this time of year. 

This photo is an experiment in kinetic light painting, where I move the camera while it exposes a shot, typically with a ND9 filter in shaded areas. I've been shooting kinetic light paintings with fairly linear motion lately.

This was all done in camera, processed in Camera Raw.

For more kinetic light paintings visit my Light Paintings Set on 500px.

photos.name: Workin' On Leavin' The Livin'
photos.description: A whirlwind of surreal textures confront the viewer. Swirling lines flow into gradients of natural light. Vibrant greens and blues harmonize into a flowing zen-like aesthetic. Most light painting photographers choose a flashlight, but since I began working in the medium of photography I felt it was more natural to use the camera as the paintbrush. Kinetic light painting usually consists of perfect geometric form, but I prefer the somewhat incidental nature of quick, gestural movements with the camera. 1-6 second exposures either at night or in properly lit daylight yield extraordinary visions of nature. This photo is also a tribute to Modest Mouse, who consistantly has inspried my creative process through the years. I invite you to take a look at my kinetic light paintings, you may find some interesting work. I will be uploading 1-2 a day on 500px for the next month. Find all my light paintings in my set on 500px. 500px.com/stevebelovarich/sets/light_paintings

photos.name: Bleeding Autumn
photos.description:
Movement lines spread across the frame, the light piercing the autumnal trees streaking past the viewer at the speed of light. The autumn colors bleed.

I make quick gestural movements during long exposures. The outcome is somewhat unpredictable, so I find that it helps to use natural gradients and color combinations, sometimes with ND. This shot was taken in the middle of Griffith Park in Los Angeles. Processed in Camera Raw.

photos.name: The Forests In My Mind
photos.description: Caught this shot while walking in a wilderness park in Redondo Beach. Thought the colors were very representative of those found in Southern California this time of year. So many people are shooting blurred out forests, I hope this one stands out as a bit different. This photo is an experiment in kinetic light painting, where I move the camera while it exposes a shot, typically with a ND9 filter in shaded areas. I wanted to change it up a bit, since I've been shooting kinetic light paintings with fairly linear motion lately. This was all done in camera, processed in Camera Raw. For more kinetic light paintings visit my Light Paintings Set on 500px.

photos.description: This one just spoke to me, reminded me of how I envisioned the Elysian Fields with its shady parks where athletes and heroes exist in the afterlife. I'll be uploading a few more shots from this particular location this week.

I'm iinspired by springtime and summer here in Southern California at the moment, where I capture this surrealist worldview while photographing flower beds. View more kinetic light paintings in my Portfolio.

I make quick gestural movements during long exposures. The outcome is somewhat unpredictable, so I find that it helps to use natural gradients and color combinations, sometimes with ND. This shot was taken in the middle of a forest in Upstate NY. Processed in Photoshop with HDR Toning.

Light painting of the landscaped forest in Saratoga Spa State Park in Upstate, NY. Held the slightly out of focus shot, then gestured vertically. This photo is part of a series of light paintings where I create patterns of vertical lines, painting with natural light and gradients.

photos.description:
Shot this palm while zooming, thought the color and movement were nice, combined with the depth effect. I recently picked up a diesel ND filter, expect to see more light paintings from shady spots in L.A. and around California.

This photo is part of a series where I paint with light by making gestural movements with my camera. Processed with HDR in Photoshop and blended with the original.

photos.description:

Shot with Canon 7D w/ 17-40mm f/4L, ND8 filter in Redondo Beach, CA. Processed in Camera Raw.

The forest expands into sheets of light, pulsating toward  me at a wavelength imperceptible to the human eye. 

Light painting of the landscaped forest in Saratoga Spa State Park in Upstate, NY. Gestured the camera vertically, then processed the photo in Camera Raw and rotated 90 degrees. This photo is part of a series of light paintings where I create patterns of light with lines, painting with natural light and gradients.

photos.name: Round And Round
photos.description:
Please click on the photo to see on a darker background. 

This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings where I capture available light while moving the camera in expressive ways. Check out my profile for more work like this one.

photos.name: Layers
photos.description:
Painting with light is a calming, meditative act that requires precise movement to capture interesting line and form.

This kinetic light painting is part of a series of images where I create scan lines similar to a seismograph. Directed handheld movements of the camera create the lines. Processed in Camera Raw, otherwise what you see is done completely in camera. Shot in Santa Monica, CA.

Processed in Camera Raw.

photos.name: Alley
photos.description: I use the camera itself like a paintbrush at night. Instead of keeping the camera stable and painting with a light in the field of view, I create new compositions with available light by gesturally moving the camera.

photos.name: Hazy Future Memories
photos.description: I use the camera itself like a paintbrush at night. Instead of keeping the camera stable and painting with a light in the field of view, I create new compositions with available light by gesturally moving the camera. This is one of the more complex compositions from when I was still shooting film. I layered several shots on the same frame which until recently wasn't possible digitally. I gotta get my hands on a Canon 1DX.

photos.name: Gathering of the Lights
photos.description: This approach to light painting is different than most, in place of a light that I would use as a brush, the camera itself becomes the object of movement. I bend, twist and zoom during along exposures at night to achieve interesting results. This is one of my first successful attempts at light painting with a film camera. Taken with a Canon Elan 7E, probably with a crappy lens. Little processing done in Photoshop to tighten up the levels. All of the light paintings I create and done entirely in camera with little post processing.

photos.name: The Eye Of The Storm
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of abstract kinetic light paintings. I move the camera while exposing the frame. Each shot uses available light and is the original crop. Processed with Camera Raw.

photos.name: Flowing Light
photos.description:
This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings. I make handheld movements with a Canon 7D, intentionally painting with available light. The camera itself is the paintbrush, gathering light while I expose the frame for 2 secs, capturing the light bouncing off clouds during a California sunset. 

I'm pretty bored when I go shooting at home. The same landmarks, over and over again. I lay in wait for some extraordinary lighting to capture the beach and California coast. In between HDR landscapes, I find myself playing with light in different ways. With this process, you can walk up to an ordinary flower bed, set up your exposure and focus and begin painting with the flower petals. It's best to find low contrast scenes, with some amazing highlights. I pushed the contrast in this particular photo to make the sunlight coming through the trees pop even more. This shot is all about the movement, line, highlights and color. It is also the original crop.

Camera Raw -> Photoshop CC -> HDR Toning Adjustment -> Camera Raw Filter -> Reduce Noise Filter -> Curves -> Export to JPEG

photos.name: Impulses Of The Heart
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings.

photos.name: The Ordinary Is A Prison
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of abstract works that will be presented at the Kinetic Light Exhibition this coming February 2014 in Los Angeles, CA. A Kickstarter for the exhibition will be up soon. I need to raise funds to put together the show.

photos.name: I Turned And Saw The Fire For The First Time
photos.description: This photo is part of a collection of works that will be displayed at the Kinetic Light Exhibition in Los Angeles, CA this coming February 2014. A Kickstarter will be up in the next few days for the exhibit.

photos.name: When The Fire Began To Die
photos.description: This kinetic light painting is part of an ongoing series of Abstract Expressionist photographs steeped in Surrealism. The composition was done in camera, processed in Camera Raw and Photoshop CC. For more works like this one, check out my profile.

photos.name: The Clarity of Understanding
photos.description:
This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings. I make handheld movements with a Canon 7D, intentionally painting with available light. The camera itself is the paintbrush, gathering light while I expose the frame for 1-3 secs. 

This particular work is the first frame I captured during the beginning of sunset in the Sierra Mountains. The colors and vibrancy of the Mountains really inspired me while I was there. The name of the work is somewhat of a paradox, as the image itself is complex and deserves careful attention to detail.

photos.name: Motion In Nature
photos.description:
I treat my still camera like a video camera, exposing the sensor while moving for the span of seconds. Naturally occurring scenes filled with beautiful color and light are abstracted into an expression of time and space. The original subject is no longer the emphasis of the photograph, substituted by the line, color and shape of motion blurred light. Most light painting is a form of drawing, but this work is the furthest from pictorial. I don't really feel like I'm painting. The movements I make are largely influenced by my experience operating professional video equipment. 

For more shots like this one, check out my profile.

This shot was processed in Camera Raw, Photoshop CC, HDR Adjustment, Camera Raw Filter -> JPEG

photos.name: Border
photos.description:
This shot is a bit experimental, and was captured somewhat by chance. I like it because there's shape to it, even though its high contrast. The lighting is expressive. The line creates a horizon and the depth is almost otherworldly. 

"Border" is part of a series of Abstract Kinetic Light Paintings. I move the camera in expressive gestural ways. If you were watching me take the photo it might seem like a performance onto itself. I feel like I'm pushing the borders of what could be considered Photography with shots like this one.

This shot in minimal, which is why I really like it. Sometimes I get lost in the Detail slider in Camera Raw.

photos.name: Messages From The Future
photos.description: Most of my low light kinetic light paintings have an orthographic perspective, but this one is different in that it has three dimensional depth. Lately I've been trying out techniques that increase the illusion of three dimension space in the photograph, although I add a fourth dimension with the title and long exposure.

photos.name: Back In 2013
photos.description: Thought this shot was a bit different, you can make put parts of the concrete and parking lot I shot it in. It isn't a complete abstraction like most of my work and has a color palette all it's own. Almost called it "Swallowed By Concrete".

photos.name: Rapture
photos.description: This one has a different kind of depth going for it. Part of a series of Abstract Expressionist photographs, this photo has a composition all it's own. This is the original crop, processed in Photoshop and Camera Raw. All of my kinetic light paintings are for sale.View more abstract photographs in my profile and you may find one that looks great on your desktop.

photos.name: Walking In The Garden Of Good and Evil
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of Abstract Expressionist Kinetic Light Paintings by Steve Belovarich. This one is similar to 'Bloody Sunday', but I think this one may have better contrast and tone. Processed in Camera Raw, Save As JPEG (Progressive) in Photoshop CC.

photos.name: Back To 1986
photos.description: I treat my still camera like a video camera, exposing the sensor while moving for the span of seconds. Naturally occurring scenes filled with beautiful color and light are abstracted into an expression of time and space. The original subject is no longer the emphasis of the photograph, substituted by the line, color and shape of motion blurred light. Most light painting is a form of drawing, but this work is the furthest from pictorial. I don't really feel like I'm painting. The movements I make are largely influenced by my experience operating professional video equipment. This practice becomes a sort of a therapy from the boredom of shooting the same things over and over again.

photos.name: Embryonic
photos.description: This photo is part of an ongoing series of kinetic light paintings where I paint with sunlight. In this shot, I rotate the camera a 3/4 turn. producing a wave like shape. Shot with a Canon 7D, original crop and processed in Camera Raw and Photoshop CC.

photos.name: Rememberin' An Ancient Time
photos.description: This is something new, different and original. I hope you like it. I painted this by by moving the camera while exposing light from a sunset reflecting off surfaces. The line is either a car or a streetlight.

photos.name: The Dawn Of Time
photos.description: Handheld camera movement, processed in Camera Raw then HDR Adjustment in Photoshop CC. Original crop. Follow @photokinetica on Twitter!

photos.name: Ego Trippin'
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of Abstract Expressionist works. This is the original crop. I make deliberate movements with the camera to produce this work. The motion blur you see was done completely in camera and then processed in Photoshop. No retouching was done, however I do tweak the curve and pass these latest works through HDR processing to achieve a level of detail and dynamic range otherwise not found in the original.

photos.name: Opening The Doors Of Perception
photos.description: So many people photograph the underside of the Manhattan Beach Pier. I thought it was time to do something a little more original with the structure. This photo is part of a collection of kinetic photographs captured in 2013. With your help on Kickstarter, the photos will be exhibited at the Kinetic Light Exhibition in February.

photos.name: The Time Traveler
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of collection of kinetic photographs shot in 2013. The Kinetic Light Exhibition this coming February 2014 in Los Angeles will be the first public showing of the work in a gallery, but not without your support on Kickstarter! Please help fund the Kinetic Light Exhibition on Kickstarter. I originally named this "Journey Into the Subconscious Mind", but you may need to be unconscious to travel through time, so I thought it needed a new name. Its probably inspired by all the sci-fi I've watched.

photos.name: Falling From Outer Space
photos.description: If you like my work, please fund the Kickstarter. $25 donation and you get an eBook with direct downloads to HD wallpapers free for personal use on mobile devices, tablets, computers and TV screens.

photos.name: Slipping Into The Future
photos.description: This is another experiment where I a create the illusion of 3D perspective, instead of the flat lines characteristic of some of my other works. If you like my work, please fund the Kickstarter for the Kinetic Light Exhibition.

photos.name: It's Not In Your Mind
photos.description: I think I could do an entire series of just shots like this one. If you like my work, please donate to the Kickstarter.

photos.name: Staring Into The Light Of The Phoenix
photos.description: This photo is a select for the Kinetic Light Exhibition. Please help the gallery show on Kickstarter. All it takes is $5. $25 donation and you get an eBook filled with photos of the entire collection, HD digital downloads for personal use on all your devices.

photos.name: The Dawn Of Time
photos.description: Most of the kinetic photographs in this series are a commentary on our perception of time and space. Please help fund the Kickstarter for the Kinetic Light Exhibition this coming February. A $5 or $10 donation would go a long way to helping fund my first solo exhibition. Make a $25 donation and receive an eBook filled with the entire collection w/ digital downloads for use on all your devices.

photos.name: The Part Of My Heart Left Undone
photos.description: It's more about the absence of light than the light itself. This work is part of a series of kinetic photographs that will be on display at the Kinetic Light Exhibition this February in Los Angeles. Please help fund the costs of my first solo exhibition on Kickstarter, I need all the help I can get.

photos.name: The Path To Illumination
photos.description: Press H and M to see the detail in the shadows. If you like this work please donate to the Kinetic Light Exhibition on Kickstarter. I search for scenes filled with beautiful light and construct surreal abstract expressionist images by moving the camera while exposing the frame. The resulting aesthetic presents a distorted view of reality open to interpretation by the viewer. I usually don’t reveal the personal meaning in these works except for hinting at it in the title. I offer an experience for the viewer to construct their own meaning from their subconscious mind. In this way, the work is steeped in a surrealist worldview. The work questions our perceptual awareness of space and time. This series of kinetic photographs are an extension of early studies in motion photography. photos.name: Wake Me Up When The Music Stops
photos.description: I just can't get into Christmas music and when it gets stuck in my head with it's jingle jangle voodoo it bugs me. Just wake me up when it's over. This photograph shows a mix of techniques I use when creating kinetic photographs. The lines in the top center are wavy and contrasted against the background, while the bottom of the frame is minimal and is made up of blocky streaks. My current interest is moving toward the latter. It has colors I associate with Christmas, but is not a shot of Christmas lights. Those may be forthcoming if I feel so inclined.

photos.name: Quantum Leap Into A Millennial
photos.description: Found this shot in a group of selects from earlier this year. It hadn't seen the light of day until now. This shot has a lot of interesting colors, reminded me of the Navajo inspired patterns with funky colors I've seen Millennials wearing these days. I keep trying to emphasize with Millennials, but find myself relating more to Generation X or even the Greatest Generation folks that helped raise me. This photograph got a bit more processing than usual to bump the saturation and enhance the contrast. As usual the is the result of motion captured in camera, no retouching and this is the original crop.

photos.name: Reaching Twilight

photos.name: Embryonic
photos.description: This is one of the first kinetic photographs I shot this past year. The eBook I am creating for the Kinetic Light Exhibition on Kickstarter features this photograph in a series of images dealing with time travel. Questioning our perception of time is the crux of the pathos of this series of photographs. I am fascinated with the idea that our perception of time is changing as we age, by shifts in daylight savings time, and because of our engagement with technology.

photos.name: The Ether Of A New Year
photos.description: It's sometimes hard for us to predict trends in a new year. Blog writers tend to make claims on how the year will go. I'd rather be in the moment, but often find myself projecting a possible future for the industry I am in. This work is about the past, present and future. The abstract impressionistic landscapes in the series are a representation of time and space. Photography can be said to capture a moment in time, however it merely is a two dimensional representation of our natural perception of the world. Captured in Fort Bragg one morning in December, this photograph is part of a series of kinetic photography that will be featured at Gallery 381 in Los Angeles, CA this coming March 2014.

photos.name: The Illusion Of Linear Time
photos.description: Happy New Year Everyone!

photos.name: Time Keeps On Slippin'
photos.description: Happy New Year! Thank you everyone for your support this past year. I have valued your critiques and kind words about my abstract photography. However, since 500px changed the Flow I have seen a huge drop in comments on my photography, as I am sure you have too. This is one reason I've decided not to renew my Awesome account this year. To learn about how I moved my portfolio over to a custom site, read this blog post I wrote on hackerspace. Message me for pricing if you want a custom web portfolio designed using the content you've already uploaded on 500px. I am a web developer and will make a custom responsive portfolio for you to showcase your photography.

photos.name: Leavin' The Spectacle
photos.description: This photo is probably the last kinetic photograph taken in 2013 that I post to 500px and it also concludes the collection. More kinetic photographs will follow in 2014, most likely to be minimal in aesthetic and feature a lot of beach sunlight. I hope you all have a great year of photography ahead of you and encourage you to try new techniques and challenge you to photograph things you normally wouldn't think of. Let it flow and make sure it feels right, take a deep breath and snap!  Have a great year everyone!

photos.name: Succumb To The Spectacle
photos.description: We are so awash in images, so much that our visual perception becomes clouded by color and light. This photograph is an extension of the last, part of a series of kinetic photographs I will be exhibiting at Gallery 381 this spring.

photos.name: Hypnotized By The Spectacle
photos.description: The spectacle surrounds us, propagated by television, radio and the internet. The spectacle is hard to escape, as it is attractive and mesmerizing to the eye. I rarely shoot kinetic photographs in low light anymore, mostly because my Canon 7D can't handle it, too much noise. I prefer it when the frame is filled with light. This particular composition was both purposeful and accidental. It reminded me of when I started experimenting with this technique over 10 years ago at night, in the streets of Troy, NY.

photos.name: Through The Wormhole
photos.description: I usually don't shoot kinetic photographs at night. However, in Vegas I can flood the sensor with light and create an interesting perspective. This shot is part of a series of kinetic photographs taken for the Kinetic Light Exhibition. Please help fund the Kickstarter for the exhibit.

photos.name: Time Travelin'
photos.description: Part of a series of kinetic photographs that comment on our perceptual awareness of space and time, this shot is a companion to another called "The Time Traveler". If you like this work or other shots in the series, please donate to the Kickstarter that is funding my first solo exhibition of photography at Gallery 381 in Los Angeles, CA. You can get an eBook filled with the entire collection and digital downloads of the work for use on all your devices. The photos really look great on retina displays. But if you also prefer, you can get signed prints by the artist for a $50 donation or more. Less than 3 days left to donate!

photos.description: This photo is part of a series of collection of kinetic photographs shot in 2013. The Kinetic Light Exhibition this coming February 2014 in Los Angeles will be the first public showing of the work in a gallery, but not without your support on Kickstarter! Please help fund the Kinetic Light Exhibition on Kickstarter. I originally named this "Journey Into the Subconscious Mind", but you may need to be unconscious to travel through time, so I thought it needed a new name. Its probably inspired by all the sci-fi I've watched.

photos.name: A Momentary Revelation About Human Nature
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings. I move the camera while exposing the frame.

photos.name: Into The Void Of The Unconscious Mind
photos.description:
Please like and vote for my work! It may get featured in the Weekly Monday Blog Contest! 

I treat my still camera like a video camera, exposing the sensor while moving for the span of seconds. Naturally occurring scenes filled with beautiful color and light are abstracted into an expression of time and space. The original subject is no longer the emphasis of the photograph, substituted by the line, color and shape of motion blurred light. Most light painting is a form of drawing, but this work is the furthest from pictorial. I don't really feel like I'm painting. The movements I make are largely influenced by my experience operating professional video equipment. This practice becomes a sort of a therapy from the boredom of shooting the same things over and over again.

photos.name: The Burn
photos.description:
This photo is part of a series of kinetic light paintings. I make handheld movements with a Canon 7D, intentionally painting with available light. The camera itself is the paintbrush, gathering light while I expose the frame for 1-3 secs. In this case, I'm capturing the light of a California sunset.

I'm pretty bored when I go shooting at home. The same landmarks, over and over again. I lay in wait for some extraordinary lighting to capture the beach and California coast. In between HDR landscapes, I find myself playing with light in different ways. With this process, you can walk up to an ordinary flower bed, set up your exposure and focus and begin painting with the flower petals. It's best to find low contrast scenes, with some amazing highlights. I pushed the contrast in this particular photo to make the sunlight coming through the trees pop even more., making it appear like fire. This shot is the original crop.

Camera Raw -> Photoshop CS6 -> HDR Toning Adjustment -> Curves -> Export to JPEG

photos.name: The Path To Illumination
photos.description: Press H and M to see the detail in the shadows. If you like this work please donate to the Kinetic Light Exhibition on Kickstarter. I search for scenes filled with beautiful light and construct surreal abstract expressionist images by moving the camera while exposing the frame. The resulting aesthetic presents a distorted view of reality open to interpretation by the viewer. I usually don’t reveal the personal meaning in these works except for hinting at it in the title. I offer an experience for the viewer to construct their own meaning from their subconscious mind. In this way, the work is steeped in a surrealist worldview. The work questions our perceptual awareness of space and time. This series of kinetic photographs are an extension of early studies in motion photography. While futurist photographers and even the cubists in the early 20th century thought in terms of the Machine Age, this work offers a perspective from the time we currently live.

photos.description: There's only a few minutes of sunlight available to capture shots like this and "The Dawn Of Time". There are other linear kinetic light paintings in my profile, but the lighting and luminance of this one really stood out. I move the camera while exposing the frame. Southern California sunlight makes it a bit easier. I'm just waiting for an evening that's partly cloudy with sunlight bouncing purples and pinks and oranges. Shot with ND8 and Circular Polarizer. Processed in Camera Raw. This is the original crop. I always keep the motion blur in camera.

photos.name: Expressing The Inexpressible
photos.description: Kinetic light painting is a calming, meditative act. Deliberate, organic movement with the camera in properly lit environments can make interesting, dream like compositions. What was once an ordinary wilderness scene now becomes the surreal. The composition was completely done in camera, processed in Camera Raw and then post processed with the HDR Adjustment in photoshop to play around with Gamma. Watch out for several more photos with this same technique every night this week. I want to thank Susanne for being my inspiration. If you enjoy this photo, head on over to my set Light Paintings on 500px.

photos.name: Ebb And Flow
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of light paintings where I paint with natural light. Handheld long exposures reveal organic patterns of light and color unseen by the naked eye. Most light painting photographers choose a flashlight, but since I began working in the medium of photography I felt it was more natural to use the camera as the paintbrush. Kinetic light painting usually consists of perfect geometric form, but I prefer the somewhat incidental nature of quick, gestural movements with the camera. 1-6 second exposures either at night or in properly lit daylight yield extraordinary visions of nature. I invite you to take a look at my kinetic light paintings, you may find some interesting work. I will be uploading 1-2 a day on 500px for the next month. Find all my light paintings in my set on 500px. 500px.com/stevebelovarich/sets/light_paintings

This particular work is the first frame I captured during the beginning of sunset in the Sierra Mountains. The colors and vibrancy of the Mountains really inspired me while I was there. The name of the work is somewhat of a paradox, as the image itself is complex and deserves careful attention to detail.

photos.name: Passing Through Gethsemane
photos.description:
This shot is part of a series of kinetic light paintings I've been working on for upcoming exhibitions. I move the camera while exposing the frame which produces this abstraction. 

I had titled another photo this but changed its name after processing this shot. This photo a bit different than the linear motions I've been making lately, more freeform and somewhat incidental. 

I shot this with a ND8 filter + Circular Polarizer, walking and moving the camera in a linear motion while exposing for 2 seconds. Even with this much light from the shot, I was able to capture an exposure with shadow and highlight.

photos.name: Ego Trippin'
photos.description: This photo is part of a series of Abstract Expressionist works. This is the original crop. I make deliberate movements with the camera to produce this work. The motion blur you see was done completely in camera and then processed in Photoshop. No retouching was done, however I do tweak the curve and pass these latest works through HDR processing to achieve a level of detail and dynamic range otherwise not found in the original.

photos.name: Fleeting Waves
photos.description:
The forest expands into sheets of light, pulsating toward  me at a wavelength imperceptible to the human eye. 

Light painting of the landscaped forest in Saratoga Spa State Park in Upstate, NY. Gestured the camera vertically, then processed the photo in Camera Raw and rotated 90 degrees. This photo is part of a series of light paintings where I create patterns of light with lines, painting with natural light and gradients.

I went back and forth with the crop until I settled on the original shot. I like to keep the composition that I made in camera, so even though its unlevel I don't really mind.
